feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 12:16AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water In The Noatak, Kobuk And Koyukuk Valleys... The northwest Interior received 2 to 5 inches of rainfall over the past week, with the heaviest amounts in the Upper Kobuk, Upper Noatak, and lower Koyukuk Valleys. Expect rivers in the Noatak, Kobuk, and Koyukuk Valleys to remain high this week. Flooding is not expected, but most gravel bars will be covered by water, and
entry.cap:areaDesc: Lower Kobuk and Noatak Valleys; Lower Koyukuk and Middle Yukon Valleys; Upper Kobuk and Noatak Valleys

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 12:16AM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Elevated Surf Today and Wednesday Along The West Coast From the Bering Strait To The Yukon Delta... A strong storm will move to the West Coast of Alaska today and into the Interior on Wednesday. South winds of 25 to 40 mph are expected along the West Coast today, diminishing tonight and Wednesday. These strong winds will cause elevated surf from the
entry.cap:areaDesc: Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; St Lawrence Island and Bering Strait Coast; Yukon Delta

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 29 at 1:47PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HEAVY RAIN FOR LATE WEEK INTO THE WEEKEND... A series of atmospheric rivers will move across the northern half of Southeast Alaska starting early Thursday near Yakutat and then sliding over the northern inner channels through Friday. While there are uncertainties on the timing and track of additional rainfall for the weekend, rain amounts of 2 to 7 inches is expected with the

entry.summary: ...A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of Choctaw, northern Clarke and southwestern Wilcox Counties through 330 PM CDT... HAZARD...Winds in excess of 40 mph and pea size hail.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued August 30 at 3:09AM PDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Hot Temperatures through Labor Day Weekend... A strong ridge of high pressure will settle over the Great Basin this week and continue into Labor Day weekend, bringing hot and dry conditions. Expect high temperatures in the upper 80s to around 100, which will be around 10 degrees above normal for this time of year. Some record high temperatures are expected.
